sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: External threats to Wetland PAs reduced through mainstreaming wetland PA considerations in sector planning
22 Increased national financing for wetland PA management funds and number of mechanisms as recorded in the financial sustainability scorecard

comment.narrative:
Baseline amount is the national budget allocation of US8795 Million per year for operation US 35170000 and infrastructure US 52780000
Financing mechanisms are mainly budget allocations There is an ecocompensation program however the funding provincial governments receive is not linked to PA management

Budget allocations for PA management operation increased by 50 over the baseline from national level sources any sources to be developed during implementation and new sustainable financing mechanisms for PAs established and operational including earmarking of ecocompensation program funding for wetland PA management

The project helps SFA in allocation of funding for wetland programme nationally The national budget allocation rises fast and now at US300 Million in 2014 26301million for operations 3699 million for infrastructure covering 63 projects with about 500000 hectares wetlands added as beneficiary The policy of central government subsidies to wetlands have been implemented very well in 2014 the central government allocated special funds to start pilot programme of farmland to wetlands pilot programme of wetland ecological compensation pilot wetland conservation incentives and the continued implementation of wetland conservation and restoration programmes 268 projects were arranged the total amount subsidies of 2014 was about USD26301million increased 12 and 54 times respectively than 2013 The specified funding allocation of 2014 is as following USD8284 million for wetlands conservation and restoration USD2467 million for pilot programme of returning farmland to wetlands USD 1052million for wetland ecological compensation programme about USD4931 million for pilot wetland conservation incentives
These figure already exceed targets for funding set forth in PD

Budget allocations for PA management operation increased by 50 over the baseline from national level sources any sources to be developed during implementation and new sustainable financing mechanisms for PAs established and operational including earmarking of ecocompensation program funding for wetland PA management

The project helps SFA in allocation of funding for wetland programme nationally The national budget allocation rises fast and now at US300 Million in 2014 26301million for operations 3699 million for infrastructure covering 63 projects with about 500000 hectares wetlands added as beneficiary The policy of central government subsidies to wetlands have been implemented very well in 2014 the central government allocated special funds to start pilot programme of farmland to wetlands pilot programme of wetland ecological compensation pilot wetland conservation incentives and the continued implementation of wetland conservation and restoration programmes 268 projects were arranged the total amount subsidies of 2014 was about USD26301million increased 12 and 54 times respectively than 2013 The specified funding allocation of 2014 is as following USD8284 million for wetlands conservation and restoration USD2467 million for pilot programme of returning farmland to wetlands USD 1052million for wetland ecological compensation programme about USD4931 million for pilot wetland conservation incentives
These figure already exceed targets for funding set forth in PD

description.narrative: 21a Safeguards from sector practices for MOA MOWR MLWR and MEP in place and in use

comment.narrative: No safeguards for wetland PAs
Safeguards in the form of standards and procedures in place for each sector and used centrally by SFA to avoid threats from external sectors

Progress under this outcome goes well and several activities have been initiated
1 A service contract entitled Development of Guidelines for Infrastructure Development and Operation and The Issuance of Official Guidelines for Fisheries Aquaculture and Agriculture in and around Wetland PAs was awarded and is in progress well and the achievements of this mission will make decision making reference for SFA and other agencies
2SFA made great efforts to guide all the provinces to implement the Wetlands conservation and management regulation issued in early of 2013 to standardize the behavior of wetland use containment of wetlands loss and damage
3SFA has reached a basic consensus with MEPMOA SOA MWR and MLR on the issues of wetland conservation legislation and the National Wetland Conservation Ordinance Draft has been improved and submitted to state council and confidently expected to be issued within 2015
4Project also make contribution to RAMSAR convention committee on technical and logistic support etc
5Project has contribute to the wetland conservation and management related policies research taken lead by the State Council and the official announcement on strengthening wetland conservation and management will be issued within 2015
An official announcement entitled Further strengthening the construction of national wetland park has been issued by SFA in 2014 No62014
Safeguards in the form of standards and procedures in place for each sector and used centrally by SFA to avoid threats from external sectors

indicator scores remain unchanged as the baseline ie 1115 of 216 in Beijing 52 and will be updated by the MTR

description.narrative: 33 Magnitude and coverage of lessons disseminated

comment.narrative: No program level system to track or disseminate lessons

Programmatic monitoring system in place as per the Program Framework and program level reporting is in place Lessons documented and shared widely Wetland PA Program Steering and Coordination Forum established

PSC meeting 2015 has been conducted successfully on Apr22232015 in Honghu county Heibei Province
Project website wwwgefwetlandcom has been established and operated information experiences and lessons sharing are more widely and efficient Wechat group has been established and use for daily communication among all projects stakeholders

description.narrative: 31 Improved data sharing platform regularly updated as indicated by use levels of data providers and data users including their usefulness

comment.narrative: No use Currently the SFA lacks a comprehensive system to manage wetland data at the subsystem level

Data sharing platform in use in the form of a virtual database containing basic wetland PA data from all the PA agencies providing necessary information for wetland PA managers for their management decision making

Data base development has been designed as a very important part under outcome 3 during the period of project implementation OWCMSFA has taken the lead and organized a group of experts to establish the virtual database by Chinese partner supporting funding based on the demands and needs of wetland development in China And the project funds planned for this purpose has been decided to shift for other policies research through the discussion with OWCMSFA and UNDP China

At the end of the project 20 of the countrys wetland PAs will have adopted the use of the METT as a regular monitoring tool

description.narrative: Wetland PA SubSystem Strengthened through Better Ecological Representation and Enhanced Management Capacity
12 Ecosystem Health Index EHI monitoring systems for monitoring wetland health finetuned and in place for the entire subsystem with a focus to reduce threats

comment.narrative: Currently no use The EHI has been developed during the PPG stage but will be finetuned based on implementation experience emerging from the provincial projects and other existing indexes eg the WEEIS Annex 1
Finetuning and wide adoption of EHI at the subsystem wetland PA level

To be updated at MTR
1A service contract entitled Development and Demonstration of Wetland Ecosystem Evaluation Index System EHI was awarded and is now in progress well and the draft report of this mission has been completed in June 2015 and distributed to all six provincial projects for further comments
2Hubei Anhui and Hainan Projects have invited experts to do the EHI in their pilot PAs and fixed the baseline of their projects The EHI has been used by Hainan Forestry department as one regular monitory tool in project pilot PAs and will be extended to other PAs in the whole Hainan Province detail see the PIR report of Hainan Project
3 The rest of provincial projects have also planned related activity in their work plan before MTR
Finetuning and wide adoption of EHI at the subsystem wetland PA level

1. Insufficient Systemic and Institutional Capacity at the National Level 2. Disconnect between the Wetland PA Sub-System and Development and Sector Planning 3. Insufficient Awareness, Knowledge and Access to Suitable Information
Component 2:Mainstreaming wetland PAs in sectoral planning Component 3:Knowledge management, lessons sharing, and awareness
Activities completed and project closed.

1.1. Coverage of natural wetlands in the national PA network increased from the baseline of 45.33% to 48%. 1.2. Ecosystem Health Index (EHI) monitoring systems for monitoring wetland health fine-tuned and in place for the entire sub-system, with a focus to reduce threats. 2.1. The national standards for wetland restoration and management in place and in use 2.2. Increased national financing for wetland PA management (funds and number of mechanisms) as recorded in the financial sustainability scorecard 3.1. Improved data sharing platform regularly updated, as indicated by use levels of data providers and data users including their usefulness. 3.2. Public and government have better understanding and better access to information about wetland issues, indicated by results of the KAP surveys (Annex 4) 3.3. Magnitude and coverage of lessons dissemin

Good Practices: Effective program coordination. Establishing a project/program steering committee and rotating the venue for the meetings among the provinces where the child projects were implementing was an effective way to promote crosssharing, organizing site visits concurrently with the PSC meetings and facilitating joint training and communication activities with the child project PMOs. Adaptive management. The project did a good job at adapting to the priorities of the national government regarding wetlands conservation and management, providing timely incremental support. Robust information management system (big data). The national wetland PA information management is comprehensive and forward-thinking, e.g., including detailed maps that are useful for local governments and PA management administrations. Informative comments included among the Financial Scorecard and Capacity Development Scorecards. The end-ofproject assessments of the GEF-5 Financial Scorecard (Part II of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard) and the UNDP Capacity Development Scorecards contained detailed, informative comments. These M&E tools were commendably filled out and can be used as a good practice example for other project teams. Lessons Learned: Insufficient validation of the project strategy at project inception. The project inception is an important phase of the project, particularly for validating the project strategy, including clarification of what is expected with respect to policy reform, the project results framework, mainstreaming of the METT and EHI tools, policy expectations, etc. Inconsistencies some tracking tool entries and insufficient quality control of M&E tools applied among the child projects. Part I of the Financial Sustainability Scorecard contains inconsistencies, e.g., regarding wetland PA coverage, and some of the METT scores for the target PA’s among the child projects contain inconsistencies (e.g., for the Altai project, PIMS 4596). Lack of a communications and knowledge management strategy. There were a number of activities on the project that were focused on communications and knowledge management, but there was a lack of a strategic approach. It would have been advisable to have developed communications and knowledge management strategy and action plan. Limited stakeholder engagement. There were some shortcomings in terms of stakeholder engagement, including the Department of Protected Areas of the NFGA (and the predecessor of this department), the MEE and the NGO sector. Program results not regularly reported. Considering the project had the role of program coordination, it would have been advisable to have prepared annual program level progress reports. Limited tracking of co-financing and coordinating with co-financing partners. Materialized government co-financing exceeded the confirmed sum at project entry; however, the project was not regularly tracking co-financing contributions, including mobilized investments and contributions from other partners.
